title: Obama defends Iran nuclear deal | Fox News
text:
Obama defends Iran nuclear deal Published July 15, 2015 Facebook 0 Twitter 0 livefyre Email Print 
President Obama on Wednesday staunchly defended the newly struck Iran nuclear deal, calling it far better than the alternative. 
During a press conference at the White House, Obama said without a deal there would be "no limits" on Iran's nuclear program and the country "could move closer to a nuclear bomb." 
With the deal, he said, "we cut off every single one of Iran's pathways to a nuclear program." 
"This deal is our best means of assuring that Iran does not get a nuclear weapon," Obama said, calling it a "historic chance" to pursue a more secure world. 
The press conference comes a day after the U.S. and five other world powers sealed the long-sought -- and controversial -- nuclear deal with Iran. 
The agreement would curb Tehran's nuclear program in exchange for valuable sanctions relief. While the United Nations will take care of implementing parts of the deal, the administration still is seeking approval from Congress, where many lawmakers remain skeptical. 
Republicans, and some Democrats, are concerned the deal legitimizes Iran's nuclear program and gives them too much in return for tightening up the possible paths to a bomb. 
But Obama argues the deal is far better than the alternative and is urging Congress to give it a chance. On Tuesday, he threatened to veto any attempt to block the international agreement. Advertisement
